moves.1... e5 2. d4: Now here follows an ominous buildup to what I thought would be an epic battle in which I would be in the lead.
moves.2... f6 3. f4 Bd6 4. Nf3 Nc6: The d-pawn must feel very threatened and yet protected at the same time.
moves.5. Bb5 a6 6. Bxc6 dxc6: My opponent thought a while before making this move... He must have been mourning the imminent loss of his d-pawn.
moves.7. dxe5: Here begins the Massacre of the King's Pawn.
moves.7... fxe5 8. fxe5 Bd7: ?? Why not save his other Bishop? This just leads to a myriad of other problems.
moves.16. Nd2 f5 17. Rf2: Taking on f5 would result in a Queen trade.
moves.17... c5 18. Qe3 b5 19. Qg3+: Here begins the beauty of the game.
I chose not to take the Queen multiple times, for aesthetic purposes.
moves.29... Rxf8 30. Rxf8+ Qg8 31. Qh6#: No Queen taken. I love this, and thoroughly enjoyed it! Please rate and comment.
